posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked:
For one of our mechanisms, the gravity holding torque produces the Kraken stall whistle sound, which annoys some of our members.

Is there a way to turn it off?

posts.name: Ethan Grieshop
posts.cooked: I’m pretty sure the only way to do that is to choose a higher gear ratio

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked:
Get one of these when they come out:

REV Robotics 2024 / 2025 General Forum

REV Robotics 2024 / 2025 General Forum

I love the stall whistle in many cases….if its supposed to stall and you hear it - great! If it’s not supposed to stall and you hear it - stop!

Good argument for having earplugs on hand for whoever it bothers. Hearing protection is super important in FRC .

posts.name: sanddrag
posts.cooked: It would be great if this feature could be turned off.

posts.name: Nate Laverdure (he/him)
posts.cooked: It’s not a “feature” that could be “turned off”. It’s an intrinsic property of the device and a consequence of doing switching at a frequency in the audible range. Right?

posts.name: Chris Bale
posts.cooked:
My impression was that this was not a mechanical byproduct of the motor stalling, but rather an intentional audio tone that was played to inform the user a stall was occurring. I was also under the impression that this is the same audio device that causes the motors to “beep” when you update them and allows you to play CHRP file sounds through them. The fact that this is also only a thing on CTRE motors seems to be evidence of this as well.

I seem to recall having a conversation once with a CTRE guy where they were saying something to the effect of that it was theoretically possible to disable the feature through firmware but that they didn’t want to do that for various reasons (though I may be misremembering it).

posts.name: Kabir
posts.cooked:
As @cbale2000 mentioned, it does seem to be an intentional feature - if it was intrinsic to the motor, there would need to be a reason why the same thing doesn’t occur on NEOs (and it couldn’t be FOC , since the stall whistle still exists without it). Also, the Falcon 500 user guide pdf lists “Stall Whistle” under the heading “Falcon 500 Features”, implying it’s intentional.

cbale2000:

it was theoretically possible to disable the feature through firmware but that they didn’t want to do that for various reasons (though I may be misremembering it).

This topic was brought up on the Discord a while ago, and the reason seemed to be something like informing users that the motor is stalling so that they don’t wonder why it encounters a thermal shutdown and/or thermal death. I think a few people did email CTRE support requesting for the stall whistle threshold to be configurable; I don’t know if that’s planned for Phoenix 6 right now.

cbale2000:

same audio device

There’s not any specific device in the motor that produces audio; the motor windings are themselves producing the tone. I’m not exactly sure how it works (I think it‘s adding a small variation in the phase power to vibrate the motor?).

posts.name: Nate Laverdure (he/him)
posts.cooked:
kn4:

Also, the Falcon 500 user guide pdf lists “Stall Whistle” under the heading “Falcon 500 Features”, implying it’s intentional.

The Falcon 500 came with a lot of marketing tripe. I think this was a “It’s a feature, not a bug” kind of statement.

posts.name: Rich Jr
posts.cooked: This is correct, its a feature  and I know multiple teams have asked CTRE if they can expose an API to turn it off, or change the threshold for when it plays based on current/load.

posts.name: Andrew Lawrence
posts.cooked: @daltzsmith if it’s just a sound file being played I humbly request adding a feature that lets teams upload our own soundbites so that my Krakens can play a MIDI sea shanty under stall conditions.

posts.name: Ben P.
posts.cooked: Adding this feature would have practical use too! Teams could change it so the noise is lower pitched to not be as annoying to some. You could even do a warning on/off pattern if its on a motor that shouldn’t stall. Could also be useful to identify which motor is stalling if you set each one to a different noise/pitch

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked: If it’s your drive motors, use “Roll the Old Chariot Along” (or equivalent names of the same song) for maximum comedy.

posts.name: Mike Schreiber
posts.cooked:
If energy is going to sound, that means it’s not going to heat, right? Maybe it’s not that simple. Most teams worry about stator temps when talking about stalling a motor, but the other thing that brushless motors need to manage is the controller temp.

I suspect the lower audible frequency switching is part of the talon FX thermal management strategy at stall. Every time a FET switches it goes through a transition period (on the nano second scale) where it is generating heat. Doing this less often can make a difference in the losses (heat) at the controller. Many controllers switch above 20kHz because this audible noise is undesirable in a lot of consumer applications, but in FRC there’s a dual benefit of alerting the user and getting better thermal performance.

posts.name: jedgar6
posts.cooked: I think CTRE should log how many times and how intense each stall is. Depending on the severity your stall, the license fee for Phoenix Pro goes up (like insurance premiums).
